title: Johnson & Johnson Tylenol Crisis
summary: The 1982 Tylenol poisoning crisis and how Johnson & Johnson's transparent response became a gold standard in crisis PR.
content:
Case Study: J&J Tylenol Crisis

In 1982, seven people died after taking cyanide-laced Tylenol capsules in Chicago. Johnson & Johnson faced a catastrophic crisis that threatened to destroy the brand.

Crisis Response

J&J immediately recalled 31 million bottles of Tylenol, cooperated fully with authorities, and communicated openly with the media and public. CEO James Burke held press conferences and prioritised consumer safety over profits.

Results

Despite the initial devastation, J&J's transparent handling of the crisis is credited with saving the brand. Tylenol recovered its market share within a year. The case set the global standard for crisis communications.

Key Learnings

Speed, transparency, and placing public safety above profits are the cornerstones of effective crisis communication. Never minimise or deflect when lives are at risk.
